messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Resolving Matrix Spencer Conjecture Up to Poly-logarithmic Rank

Paper Abstract: We give a simple proof of the matrix Spencer conjecture up to poly-logarithmic rank: given symmetric d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d matrices A1,…,Ansubscript𝐴1…subscript𝐴𝑛A_{1},\ldots,A_{n} each with ‖Ai‖𝗈𝗉≤1subscriptnormsubscript𝐴𝑖𝗈𝗉1\|A_{i}\|_{\mathsf{op}}\leq 1 and rank at most n/log3⁡n𝑛superscript3𝑛n/\log^{3}n, one can efficiently find ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1 signs x1,…,xnsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1},\ldots,x_{n} such that their signed sum has spectral norm ‖∑i=1nxi​Ai‖𝗈𝗉=O​(n)subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝐴𝑖𝗈𝗉𝑂𝑛\|\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}A_{i}\|_{\mathsf{op}}=O(\sqrt{n}). This result also implies a log⁡n−Ω​(log⁡log⁡n)𝑛Ω𝑛\log n-\Omega(\log\log n) qubit lower bound for quantum random access codes encoding n𝑛n classical bits with advantage ≫1/nmuch-greater-thanabsent1𝑛\gg 1/\sqrt{n}. Our proof uses the recent refinement of the non-commutative Khintchine inequality in [Bandeira, Boedihardjo, van Handel, 2022] for random matrices with correlated Gaussian entries.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Dense quantum coding and quantum finite automata",
        "Strong converse for identification via quantum channels",
        "Balancing vectors and gaussian measures of n-dimensional convex bodies",
        "Constructive algorithms for discrepancy minimization",
        "On a generalization of iterated and randomized rounding",
        "Matrix concentration inequalities and free probability",
        "Better algorithms and hardness for broadcast scheduling via a discrepancy approach",
        "Roth’s estimate of the discrepancy of integer sequences is nearly sharp",
        "“integer-making” theorems",
        "An elementary proof of a more general matrix discrepancy bound",
        "Online vector balancing and geometric discrepancy",
        "Flow time scheduling and prefix beck-fiala",
        "Deterministic discrepancy minimization",
        "Twice-ramanujan sparsifiers",
        "The discrepancy method: randomness and complexity",
        "A panorama of discrepancy theory, volume 2107",
        "A new framework for matrix discrepancy: Partial coloring bounds via mirror descent",
        "Efficient algorithms for discrepancy minimization in convex sets",
        "On some vector balancing problems",
        "Extremal properties of orthogonal parallelepipeds and their applications to the geometry of banach spaces",
        "Matrix discrepancy from quantum communication",
        "Balancing covariates in randomized experiments using the gram-schmidt walk",
        "Online geometric discrepancy for stochastic arrivals with applications to envy minimization",
        "Four deviations suffice for rank 1 matrices",
        "Constructive discrepancy minimization by walking on the edges",
        "Inégalités de khintchine dans cp​(1<p<∞)subscript𝑐𝑝1𝑝c_{p}(1<p<\\infty)",
        "Non commutative khintchine and paley inequalities",
        "Deterministic discrepancy minimization via the multiplicative weight update method",
        "Geometric discrepancy: An illustrated guide, volume 18",
        "Discrepancy and beating the union bound",
        "Optimal private halfspace counting via discrepancy",
        "Interlacing families ii: Mixed characteristic polynomials and the kadison—singer problem",
        "The geometry of differential privacy: the sparse and approximate cases",
        "Sums of random hermitian matrices and an inequality by rudelson",
        "Introduction to operator space theory",
        "Approximating bin packing within o (log⁡O​P​T∗log⁡log⁡O​P​T𝑂𝑃𝑇𝑂𝑃𝑇\\log{OPT}*\\log\\log{OPT}) bins",
        "Constructive discrepancy minimization for convex sets",
        "Linear size sparsifier and the geometry of the operator norm ball",
        "Vector balancing in lebesgue spaces",
        "Six standard deviations suffice",
        "Topics in random matrix theory, volume 132",
        "An introduction to matrix concentration inequalities",
        "Second-order matrix concentration inequalities",
        "High-dimensional probability: An introduction with applications in data science",
        "Modern aspects of random matrix theory, volume 72",
        "A matrix hyperbolic cosine algorithm and applications"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Resolving Matrix Spencer Conjecture Up to Poly-logarithmic Rank, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
